value.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: the amount of money that something is worth
value.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: The alterations doubled the value of the house.
value.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: used to say that something is worth what you pay for it, or not worth what you pay for it
value.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: The lunch special is really good value.
At only £45 a night, the hotel is great value for money.
Every customer is looking for value for money.
value.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: the importance or usefulness of something
value.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: The locket has great sentimental value (=importance because it was a gift, it reminds you of someone etc).
His research has been of little practical value.
The Sioux Indians placed a high value on generosity.
place/put a high value on something
A group of athletes spoke to the students about the value of a college education.
value.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: a mathematical quantity shown by a letter of the alphabet or sign
value.translation[0].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 1: the amount of money that something is worth
value.translation[0].note_box[0].section: The dollar has been steadily increasing in value.
There is a risk that the shares may fall in value.
The house doubled in value over two years.
It’s hard to put a value on something so unusual.
The value of the land had increased by $2m.
The value of your investment may fall.
Good quality furniture should hold its value.
You should insure any goods of high value.
The low value of the dollar will benefit tourists.
The mortgage is more than the house’s current market value.
They made an attempt to assess the cash value of the contract.
The tickets are selling for far more than their face value.
The real value of their salaries has fallen.
Drugs with a street value of £1,600 were found in the car.
There was a sudden drop in the value of oil.
We saw a rapid increase in the land’s value.
value.translation[0].note_box[1].heading: – Meaning 3: the importance or usefulness of something
value.translation[0].note_box[1].section: These drugs are of great value in treating cancer.
The information was of little value.
place/put a high value on something
Our society places a high value on education.
He wanted to achieve something of lasting value.
The ring wasn’t expensive but had great sentimental value.
The nutritional value of cereals can vary.
value.translation[0].note_box[2].heading: – Meaning 6:
value.translation[0].note_box[2].section: traditional values
He called for a return to traditional values.
moral values
She had her own set of moral values.
cultural/social values
a book about a clash between British and Chinese cultural values
The films of the time reflected these changing social values.
spiritual values
We have replaced our spiritual values with materialism.
human values
basic human values such as honesty, decency, and duty
somebody’s core values
The party needs to express its core values clearly.
hold/have values
People brought up in different times hold different social values.
share somebody’s values
They vote for the candidate who shares their values.
uphold values
The new party was dedicated to upholding traditional values.
a set of values
The young have a completely different set of values.
value.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to think that someone or something is important
value.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: Mr. Yeo valued Jan for her hard work.
value.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to decide how much money something is worth, by comparing it with similar things
value.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: We decided to get the house valued.
Paintings valued at over $200,000 were stolen from her home.
value.translation[1].definitions[1].note: Value is usually passive in this meaning
value.translation[2].definitions[0].defi: the amount of money something is worth
value.translation[2].definitions[0].exam: The dangers associated with hazardous waste clearly outweigh itscommercial value.
The company’scurrent value is estimated at £300 million.
A price rise wouldincrease thedollar value of US oil production by $31 billion a year.
value.translation[2].definitions[1].defi: if something is good, excellent etc value, it is of good quality, considering its price or you get a large amount for the price
value.translation[2].definitions[1].exam: Local firms seem to offerthe best value for money.
value.translation[2].definitions[2].defi: the principles and practices that a business or organization thinks are important and which it tries to follow
value.translation[2].definitions[2].exam: Our vision for the new century calls for less consumerism and more attention to human values.
value.translation[3].definitions[0].defi: to decide how much something is worth, especially by comparing it with other, similar things
value.translation[3].definitions[0].exam: It’s almost impossible to value a media property fairly in the current economic climate.
Legal & General plc agreed to sell its insurance unit in adeal valued at £140 million.
